Confounding occurs when the association between an exposure and an outcome is distorted by the presence of another factor, which is associated with both the exposure and outcome. In this study, the presence of acid reflux is a confounding factor that affects the relationship between smoking and Barrett esophagus. When stratified by acid reflux, the effect of smoking is different, indicating confounding. Random error is not likely, as the study had a large sample size and significant results. Effect modification occurs when the magnitude or direction of the association between an exposure and an outcome varies depending on the level of another factor. Stratification is a technique used to examine the relationship between two variables by dividing the study population into subgroups. While stratification is used in this study, it is not the best explanation for the results.
